entry.summary: Sim: FS24. Aerosoft CRJ owners awaiting the launch of the CRJ v2 will have to wait a little bit longer than first anticipated, as the release has been delayed by one week. Nearly four years after its initial release, the CRJ is receiving a free v2 update, set to feature a remodelled cabin and an improved flight model. However, Aerosoft has decided to push back the update by one week to ensure the best possible experience for users at launch. Originally scheduled for March 25th, the update is now set to launch on April 1st â Benjamin from Aerosoft shared an official statement earlier today: â âWe would like to inform you that the CRJ v2 update has been delayed by one week. entry.title: UFK Announces Airbus Steering Console
entry.summary: Sim: OTHER. Universal Flight Kit, one of the new players in the world of flight sim hardware producers, has just announced their first product - the Airbus Steering Console. As the name suggests, the console is a 1:1 replica of the A320 steering console, with a 12-bit plug-and-play steering tiller with a metal base, 5V console/floor light, and attachment templates for various sidesticks (some of them being VKB, VIRPIL, Thrustmaster). As mentioned earlier, the console features an aluminum steering tiller, along with a functional PEDAL DISC button with a metal base, realistic amber built-in backlit panel (BIBL - one of their upcoming products), aluminum trash tray with a lid, and comes with screws, hardware and instruction manual. The console is made out of an MDF frame and has realistic vent grills. UKFâs newest product can be bough from their website for $299.95 during the pre-order period, and $399.99 as a standard price.The shipment begins on 2nd April, and it is also possible to order the F/O side version. It is compatible with all FS20 and FS24 aircrafts (including the most popular ones coming from developers like Fenix, PMDG, iniBuilds, Aerosoft, FBW, FSLabs, ProSim etc.), and with X-Plane 12 and ToLiss products.Â If you enjoy our content and want to support Threshold, consider joining us on Patreon!

entry.title: Fenix Announces A320NEO family for Microsoft Flight Simulator
entry.summary: Sim: FS24. Fenix has just posted its 2025 roadmap, detailing planned updates for the current A320 CEO family, compatibility improvements for MSFS 2024, and a new NEO variant. A320 and A321 NEO Announcement The major highlight of the roadmap is the announcement of an all-new A320 and A321 NEO. After extensive research and development, Fenix has created a completely new âNEOâ standard ECAM system from the ground up, which is independent of ProSim. This advancement allows for even deeper system modeling. This is not merely an updated A320 CEO with new engines; it is a fully developed A320 NEO simulation. According to Fenix, the entire aircraft has been rewired, encompassing every sensor and generator. They have also developed a fully functional DRAIMS panel, although visuals are not yet available for display. Both the CFM LEAP engine and the Pratt and Whitney Geared Turbofan will be fully represented in the simulation. Additionally, the Fenix A320 NEO will be a standalone product, meaning that prior ownership of the A320 CEO family is not a requirement. Upcoming Big Fenix Update Fenix has announced that a major update for the A320 CEO family will be released in a couple of weeks. This update will include the addition of A139 sharklets, the implementation of the Weather Radar, and new landing dynamics that enhance flare and ground effect behavior. Several upgrades to the Electronic Flight Bag (EFB) will also be introduced, such as support for Lido charts and a improvedV-Speeds calculations. Additionally, there will be audio improvements, including a new 3D AEVC soundscape for the flight deck and a redesigned IAAE V2500 soundset. Fenix says they will provide a full changelog shortly. â For more details on the Fenix A320 NEO and A321 NEO, along with the upcoming big Fenix update, refer to Fenixâs website. â If you enjoy our content and want to support Threshold, consider joining us on Patreon â

entry.title: ST Simulations Releases Bovec Airport for MSFS 2024
entry.summary: Sim: FS24. ST Simulations recently released their rendition of Bovec Airport (LJBO) for Microsoft Flight Simulator 2024, which serves the municipality of Tolmin in Slovenia. Built in 1962, Bovec is an important airfield in the country. It is located in the Slovenian Julian Alps at an elevation of nearly 1450 feet, which makes it perfect for parachuting events (which are held yearly) and general aviation. Its single 900x40-meter asphalt runway and slightly high elevation make it a great challenge regardless of the size of the airplane. The scenery features an accurate rendition of the airport, with custom 3D models and an up-to-date ground layout. It also offers performance-friendly optimization with MSFS 2024âs new LOD system, a custom hangar with an interior, landside buildings, custom objects, and more. entry.title: Laminar Research Releases X-Plane 12.2.0 Update
entry.summary: Sim: X-Plane. Laminar Research recently released a major update to X-Plane 12, which brings massive improvements to cloud rendering, lighting, environmental effects, and graphics performance. Their graphics team has been working to mitigate the famed dark cockpit issue, bringing significantly improved interior rendering quality. The light coming into the cockpit correctly follows the aircraft's contours and structural details. Furthermore, the graphics engine's exposure handling has also been improved, bringing exposure fusionâa familiar feature on most modern smartphonesâto the virtual realm of X-Plane 12. It consists of taking multiple photos at various levels of exposure and then automatically stitching them together, yielding a potentially impressive-looking result.Â The sky brightness has also been tweaked to ensure it's more natural and doesn't burn people's retinas. Ground object brightness values have also been tweaked to ensure they are not overly bright. Their graphics engine as a whole has also undergone changes, with an upgrade to their shader compiler, which manages resources more efficiently and thus brings smoother performance figures. Texture handling has also been tweaked to ensure faster loading times and more efficient rendering. Their VRAM management method has also been tweaked, ensuring it prioritizes smaller memory requests before large ones, aiding total memory allocation. Additionally, it makes multiple attempts to allocate memory before giving up, allowing the system to free up space when needed and ultimately reduce the chances of blurry textures or slow performance overall. The cloud rendering system has also been changed, with a small radius surrounding the camera's viewport sporting high-quality clouds, nearly eliminating cloud pixelation effects around the airplane. They hint at it being a stepping stone to other cool rendering effects in the future. Last but not least, they have also changed how their light rendering system works by breaking them into tiles, yielding better performance in demanding environments such as large airports and cities. In addition, they have also made minor changes to colors, bringing more realistic color accuracy, improved sky rendering, better cloud shadows, cloud shadows on clouds, cloud-aware ambient light, and more realistic shadows overall. Detail has also been enhanced on surface textures around airports, and weather effects now also show outside of the airport's area, accumulating on main roads, as suggested by the community. â The complete changelog follows below: â Known Issues â Fixes and Enhancements General â Graphics â â Scenery â The update is currently available on the public_beta branch on Steam. entry.title: Aerosoft Releases Dortmund Airport for MSFS 20/24
entry.summary: Sim: FS24. Aerosoft has recently released its rendition of Dortmund Airport (EDLW) for Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020 and 2024. Located only 6.2 miles east of Dortmund, this international airport serves over 3 million passengers each year. The airport began its first commercial flights in 1925, and service continued to expand until the Second World War, during which it served as a German airbase. After the war, commercial service to the airport was not reinstated until 1979. Construction of a new terminal started in 1998 and was completed in 2000. Since then, the airport has experienced rapid growth in traffic. Today, airlines such as Condor, Eurowings, Wizz Air, and many others provide a variety of year-round and seasonal destinations, resulting in over 3 million passengers traveling through the airport each year. The scenery includes various features such as terminal interiors, animated passengers, custom jetways, functional VDGS, a custom GSX profile, and much more.
